newsitem.title: UK: Russia Vnesh debt is a long-term buy - DMG.
newsitem.headline: Russia Vnesh debt is a long-term buy - DMG.

text.p: Likelihood the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will resume lending to Russia and the 1997 budget will get through parliament makes Russia's Vneshekonombank debt attractive, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell said on Wednesday.
"We are moving to a short-term neutral, long-term overweight recommendation on Vnesh from our previous underweight recommendation," the bank's head of emerging market research Paul Luke said.
Earlier, IMF officials said they had recommended the IMF's board meet on Friday to decide whether to pay out a delayed loan.
Luke said it was unlikely the board would meet unless IMF staff had been assured the budget would pass and be an acceptable basis for disbursements under the IMF's programme.
Though banks have been big sellers of the former Soviet debt, which is close to being restructured, sales are likely to slow with holidays approaching, Luke said in a research report.
"With this supply gradually receding, the market will be able to focus a bit more on relative value, in which case Vnesh looks cheap."
Dollar Vnesh has an implied spread of 792 basis points compared to Mexico's UMS issue maturing in 2026 of only 473 points, though the two countries share the same credit rating.

When the Vnesh is finally restructured, possibly by the end of March, all major global fixed income indices will increase Russia's weightings. That will mean a major change in the acceptability of Russian risk.
